Ammonia has long been regarded as a high-quality zero-carbon fuel; however, limitations in its combustion characteristics have restricted its practical applications. Catalytic combustion is considered an effective solution to overcome the challenges associated with ammonia combustion. In this study, we successfully synthesized a copper-cerium binary catalyst (Cu-CeOx) using the sol-gel method, demonstrating outstanding performance for NH3 catalytic combustion. Through in-situ DRIFTS results, we observed that the 15Cu-CeOx catalyst exhibits both i-SCR and -NH mechanisms. The oxygen concentration affects the N2 selectivity by modulating the overoxidation of NH3. Under high oxygen concentrations, high temperatures promote the excessive oxidation of NH3, and ammonia combustion through the i-SCR mechanism. Conversely, the oxygen concentration was equal to NH3 reaction stoichiometry, the overoxidation of NH3 is limited, and ammonia combustion proceeds through the NH mechanism, resulting in higher N2 selectivity. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Catalytic combustion Copper-cerium binary catalyst Oxygen concentration N2 selectivity Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Ammonia stands out as an exceptional energy storage carrier, has a well-established production process, notable energy density (3160 Wh L−1) [1], convenient transportation and storage capabilities (liquefied at 1 MPa at room temperature), and a commendable safety profile (110 octane with good resistance to detonation) [2]. However, the effective utilization of ammonia through combustion encounters various challenges [3]. Previous studies have focused on ammonia-doped combustion in power plants, mixed ammonia-hydrogen combustion [4], and mixed ammonia-hydrocarbon combustion [3,5]. These approaches have not fully unfolded the advantages of ammonia as an alternative fuel. Catalytic combustion emerges as a promising avenue, offering the dual advantages of lowering ammonia combustion temperatures and mitigating NOx emissions, positioning it as the optimal method for ammonia application [6]. Despite the promising potential of catalytic ammonia combustion, research in this field remains relatively constrained. Early studies on ammonia oxidation primarily focused on addressing ammonia escape in NH3-SCR systems. Although the catalysts designed for this purpose may not be entirely suitable for the catalytic combustion of ammonia [7], these studies still offer guidance for the design of ammonia combustion catalysts. In the exploration of the catalytic oxidation of ammonia, researchers have observed that noble metal catalysts, including silver [8], palladium [9], and platinum [10], exhibit heightened activity but diminished N2 selectivity [11]. In this context, transition metals, particularly copper-based catalysts, have demonstrated commendable catalytic activity and N2 selectivity [12-15]. Notably, the Al2O3-supported Cu-based catalysts exhibit robust thermal stability [16]. The bimetallic catalyst prepared by the co-impregnation method, composed of noble metals and copper, can possess both the high activity of noble metal-based catalysts and the high N2 selectivity of copper-based catalysts. [17,18]. Considering the critical factors of catalyst performance and production cost, copper-based catalysts emerge as the most promising candidates for practical applications. Qu and colleagues successfully synthesized CuO@CeO2 catalyst through hydrothermal method. On this catalyst, the coexistence of Cu2+/Cu+ mixed structure disrupts the initial crystal structure of pure CuO, thereby promoting the activation of oxygen species and enhancing the catalytic activity of the catalyst [19]. After undergoing a special oxidation–reduction treatment, the Cu-SAPO-34 catalyst can form copper superoxide, significantly enhancing its activity under low-temperature conditions. [20]. Consequently, the specific form of copper presence emerges as a pivotal factor directly influencing catalyst performance [21]. This perspective finds support in previous investigations on diverse copper-based catalysts, including CuO-Al2O3 [16,22], CuO-SiO4, CuO-SSZ-13 [13,23,24], CuOCeO2 [25] and CuO-ZrO2 [26] In the study of ammonia catalytic combustion, Satoshi et al. summarized the activity of 3d transition metal oxides from high to low as follows: MnO2 > Co3O4 > CuO > Fe2O3 ≈ V2O5 > NiO [27]. Given the high operating temperatures of the catalytic process, researchers commonly employ Al2O3, SiO2, or composite materials as carriers for catalyst preparation through impregnation methods [28-30]. Alternatively, using special methods like FSP (Flame Spray Pyrolysis) and hydrothermal synthesis to produce catalysts with unique structures has been shown to enhance the stability of the catalyst [31,32]. CeO2 exhibits excellent thermal stability, and the combination of copper and cerium enhances the oxidizing ability of the catalysts [14,26,33]. However, only a few research reports exist on copper-cerium catalysts in ammonia catalytic combustion. Additionally, numerous studies have indicated that higher N2 selectivity can be achieved by adjusting the oxygen concentration [34], but few have explored the underlying causes of this phenomenon. In this study, we employed the sol-gel method to prepare Cu-CeOx catalysts with varying copper content and prepare CuO and CeO2. These catalytic performance and N2 selectivity were systematically evaluated over a wide temperature range from 200 °C to 650 °C. Additionally, comprehensive characterizations of the catalysts were conducted, and the impact of oxygen concentration on catalytic activity and N2 selectivity was thoroughly investigated. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation We synthesized copper-cerium binary catalysts with varying copper content using the sol-gel method. Initially, a specific quantity of copper nitrate and cerium nitrate was measured based on the desired copper oxide mass ratio. These two precursors were dissolved in 100 mL of deionized water and stirred for 30 min in a water bath at 80 °C. Subsequently, an amount of citric acid was added to the solution, ensuring that the molar ratio of metal cations to citric acid was 1:1.6. Stir continuously for 30 min. Add a quantity of ammonia solution to adjust the pH to 7 and continue stirring until a gel is formed. The resulting samples were placed in a desiccator and dried at 120 °C overnight. The dried samples were calcined in a muffle furnace at 500 °C for 5 h to obtain the target catalysts, denoted as XCu-CeOx according to the mass ratio of copper oxide content. CuO and CeO2 are prepared using the same method. 2.2 Catalyst characterization and activity test The catalysts were characterized as follows. Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area (SBET) was determined using Micromeritics ASAP 2460 with nitrogen as the adsorption and desorption gas at 200 °C for 6 h. X-ray diffraction spectra (XRD) were obtained via a Bruker D8 Advance instrument (Germany) scanning from 5 to 90° at a 2°/min speed. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were also acquired using the Thermo Scientific K-Alpha instrument (U.S.A). H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) experiments were carried out using the PX200A. Subsequently, the catalysts were evaluated for ammonia catalytic combustion under specific conditions: 2.0 % NH3, varying O2 concentrations (3/2.25/1.65/1.5/1.35 %), maintaining N2 balance, with a total flow of 100 cm3 min−1 and W/F = 4.0 × 10−4 g min cm−3. The oxygen equivalent ratio for NH3 combustion is expressed as λ = ( P O 2 P N H 3 ) exp / ( P O 2 P N H 3 ) stioichiom . In-situ diffuse reflectance infrared FTIR spectra (ERIFTS) were recorded using an FTIR spectrometer (Nicolet iS50) equipped with an MCT detector cooled by liquid nitrogen. From Fig 1(a), it is evident that the catalytic activity of all Cu-CeOx catalysts is superior to that of CuO and CeO2, with 15Cu-CeOx exhibiting the highest catalytic activity. In the study of N2 selectivity, at low temperatures, all catalysts did not show a clear pattern. However, at high temperatures, the N2 selectivity of 15Cu-Cex, 20Cu-CeOx, 30Cu-CeOx, and CuO is comparable to and higher than that of 10Cu-CeOx and CeO2. In this study, we posit that the N2 selectivity of the catalysts is correlated with the copper oxide content, with higher copper oxide content leading to increased selectivity. Overall, 15Cu-CeOx demonstrates higher catalytic activity and good N2 selectivity, showcasing significant application potential. However, even in the case of CuO, which shows the highest N2 selectivity in this study, the N2 selectivity is still below 90 %. Lower N2 selectivity implies substantial emissions of nitrogen oxides during the reaction process. This contributes to environmental pollution and leads to a significant loss of energy, thereby diminishing the energy utilization efficiency of ammonia combustion. Therefore, enhancing N2 selectivity during the catalytic combustion process is imperative. 3.1.2 Catalyst characterization Considering that the catalytic activity of all Cu-CeOx catalysts is superior to that of CuO and CeO2, and the differences in catalytic activity among these Cu-CeOx catalysts are not significant, we have decided to characterize only 15Cu-CeOx, CuO, and CeO2. The catalytic performance and BET characterization results of the catalysts are listed in Table 1 . The data from the table indicates that the pore sizes of the three catalysts are similar, suggesting that the diffusion ability of reactants on the catalyst surface is not the main factor affecting the catalyst activity in this experiment. However, there is a significant difference in the specific surface areas among the three catalysts, with the specific surface area of 15Cu-CeOx (49.2 m2/g) being significantly greater than that of CeO2 (37.7 m2/g) and CuO (2.97 m2/g). This implies that the active substances on the 15Cu-CeOx catalyst are more uniformly dispersed, providing more active sites. In contrast, due to CuO's extremely low specific surface area, the number of active sites available for participating in the reaction is limited, resulting in lower catalytic activity compared to 15Cu-CeOx. Fig. 2 (a) depicts the XRD patterns of the CuO, CeO2, and Cu-CeOx catalysts. By comparing with standard reference patterns, it can be determined that CeO2 exhibits characteristic peaks at 28.5, 33.1, 47.5, and 56.3°, representing the 111, 220, and 311 crystal planes of CeO2, respectively. Meanwhile, CuO shows characteristic peaks at 35.5 and 38.7°, corresponding to CuO's 11–1 and 111 crystal planes. Analysis of the diffraction peak half-width for each catalyst reveals that the diffraction peaks of CeO2 and CuO are sharp with a small half-width, indicating good crystallinity. In contrast, the half-width of the diffraction peaks for 15Cu-CeOx significantly increases, suggesting lower crystallinity and the presence of numerous defects in its crystal structure. Additionally, the CuO diffraction peak on 15CuOCeOx is very small, indicating good dispersion of copper species on the catalyst and the formation of smaller particle sizes. After treating the catalyst at a temperature of 500 °C and λ = 2 for 60 min, we conducted H2-TPR (Hydrogen Temperature Programmed Reduction) analysis, and the results are shown in Fig. 2(b). CeO2 exhibits two smaller reduction peaks, with the 350–550 °C peak attributed to the reduction of Ce4+, and peaks above 600 °C attributed to the reduction of bulk CeO2 [35]. CuO shows two reduction peaks in the 150–250 °C range, with the 170 °C peak attributed to highly dispersed sub-nanometer CuOx and the 190 °C peak associated with nanometer CuOx [36]. A new reduction peak appears at 135 °C for the 15Cu-CeOx catalyst, attributed to the reduction of the Cu-O-Ce solid solution [19]. Notably, the maximum reduction peak for 15Cu-CeOx is at 155 °C, corresponding to sub-nanometer CuOx. This temperature is lower than the 170 °C reduction temperature of sub-nanometer CuOx on CuO, indicating a lower reduction temperature due to interactions between copper and cerium. Combining H2-TPR, XRD, and BET analyses, we infer that the 15Cu-CeOx catalyst has a larger specific surface area and higher dispersion of copper oxide, exposing more active sites. Additionally, a Cu-O-Ce solid solution with strong redox capability is formed on the copper-cerium catalyst, ultimately enhancing the catalyst's activity. XPS characterization was conducted to assess the impact of elemental valence on catalyst performance. After fitting and integrating the peaks, the results were analyzed, with Fig. 2(c), (d), and (e) displaying the fitting outcomes and Table 2 . summarizing the integration results. Notably, the atomic ratio of Ce3+/(Ce3+ + Ce4+) in 15Cu-CeOx is slightly lower than that in CeO2,it is shown that the interaction between Cu-Ce causes Ce to exist in a higher valence state. Significantly, the 1.57 % higher Cu2+/(Cu2++Cu+) ratio in 15Cu-CeOx compared to CuO infers the potential influence of Cu-Ce interactions, leading to a more oxidizing Cu2+ state. The active oxygen content is a crucial parameter influencing the oxidizing ability of catalysts. The Oactive /(Oactive + Olattice) ratios for the 15Cu-CeOx, CuO, and CeO2 catalysts were found to be 36.48 %, 52.04 %, and 34 %, respectively. Despite the considerably higher Oactive/(Oactive+Olattice) ratio of copper oxide compared to other catalysts, its catalytic activity is lower than that of 15Cu-CeOx. This disparity can be attributed to significant variations in the integrated area of the O1s XPS peaks among these catalysts, signifying differences in the total oxygen content on the catalyst surfaces. Consequently, a direct comparison of Oactive/(Oactive+Olattice) ratios lacks substantive significance. Furthermore, it is emphasized that assessing catalytic activity solely based on active oxygen content is not sufficiently accurate. 3.2 Influence of oxygen concentration 3.2.1 Activity and N2 selectivity at different oxygen concentrations We selected 15Cu-CeOx to investigate the impact of different oxygen concentrations on the catalytic combustion of ammonia, as shown in Fig. 3 and control experiments in the supporting information. For the deactivated catalyst (Fig. S1), decreasing the oxygen concentration decreases of ammonia conversion over the entire temperature range while increasing N2 selectivity. It is noteworthy that, at low temperatures, the ammonia conversion rate and N2 selectivity are independent of λ. This phenomenon is consistent with observations made by Hinokuma et al. in the study of aged copper-based catalysts such as CuOx/Al2O3 [18]. This behavior is attributed to the role of surface lattice oxygen in CuOx, which acts as a reactant for adsorbed NH3, indicating that 15Cu-CeOx follows the Mars-van Krevelen mechanism for catalytic NH3 combustion at low temperatures. Fig. 3 shows that at λ > 1, the NH3 conversion rate can reach 100 % at high temperatures, but the N2 selectivity is relatively poor. As λ decreases, N2 selectivity increases, nearly 100 % at λ = < 1. For the deactivated catalyst, the N2 selectivity is only 80 % at λ=1, which indirectly demonstrates the role of the catalyst in enhancing N2 selectivity. Conversely, when λ ≤ 1, although N2 selectivity is high, the ammonia conversion rate is insufficient, leading to significant NH3 escape and energy loss. Moreover, it is noteworthy that when λ ≤ 1, the conversion rate of ammonia exhibits a decreasing trend within the temperature range from 400 °C to 650 °C. This phenomenon is attributed to the diminished capability of the catalyst to capture O2 at higher temperatures, resulting in an insufficient amount of O2 available for the reaction with NH3. So, to achieve complete ammonia conversion, it is necessary to maintain λ > 1 in the combustion mixture. However, increasing λ reduces N2 selectivity, so careful consideration of λ values is required to ensure high N2 selectivity while achieving complete ammonia conversion. 3.2.2 Effect of λ on the catalyst redox capacity Fig. 3 emphasizes the pronounced impact of λ on the catalytic performance of the catalyst. To further investigate the role of λ in the reaction, the catalyst underwent a 500 °C treatment for 60 min in various λ atmospheres, followed by H2-TPR characterization, the results are shown in Fig. 4 . As shown in Fig. 4, with decreasing λ, the reduction temperature of the Cu-O-Ce solid solution remains constant, while the peak intensity diminishes. When λ > 1, the reduction in λ leads to an elevation in the reduction temperature of sub-nanometer CuOx, while the peak size remains unchanged. When λ ≤ 1, reducing λ increases the reduction temperature of sub-nanometer CuOx but also causes the reduction peak to decrease. As λ decreases, a new reduction peak appears around 200 °C, caused by nano CuOx[36], which is generated by the agglomeration of sub-nanometer CuOx. Although the peak position of the reduction peak varies with λ, the area of the reduction peak remains almost constant, indicating that the decrease in λ diminishes the redox capability of the catalyst, but the number of active sites does not decrease. This is because, with the reduction of λ, the oxidative capability of the reaction gas weakens, transforming into a reducing atmosphere. In this reductive environment, the active sites on the catalyst can continue functioning, sustaining the redox reaction. Therefore, the change in the area of the reduction peak is minimal. However, insufficient oxygen supply hampers the replenishment rate of surface oxygen on the catalyst. This limitation restricts the reoxidation of active sites, disrupting the original redox cycle. With the establishment of a new redox cycle, the interaction between Cu-Ce is constrained. This disruption is manifested by a decrease in the quantity of Cu-O-Ce solid solution, an increase in the reduction temperature of sub-nanometer CuOx, and the cluster of sub-nanometer CuOx to nano CuOx. 3.2.3 Analysis of NH3 and No adsorption on catalyst surface To explore the adsorption capacity of NH3 and NOx on the catalyst surface, we conducted in-situ DRIFTS experiments specifically focused on NH3 and NO + O2 adsorption. The obtained results are represented in Fig. 5 . As shown in Fig. 5(a), the peaks observed at 1636 cm−1 and 1227 cm−1 can be attributed to NH3 adsorption on the L acid present on the catalyst surface. Furthermore, the bands near 1383 cm−1 and 1342 cm−1 indicate ammonia adsorbed on the B acid. Additionally, the bands from 3200 cm−1 to 3400 cm−1 are caused by the NH stretching vibration of ammonia adsorbed on L acid [26,29]. At low temperatures (100–200 °C), ammonia primarily adheres to the catalyst's L acid. As the temperature rises to the intermediate temperature range (200–350 °C), ammonia predominantly combines with B acid. With further temperature increase, the ammonia adsorption capacity of the catalyst significantly decreases, becoming almost negligible. In addition to adsorbed NH3, various intermediate products were observed on the catalyst surface. The band at 1580 cm−1 corresponds to -NH2, 1556 cm−1 represents monodentate nitrate, 1505 cm−1 indicates HNO, 1456 cm−1 represents -NH, and 1435 cm−1 points to nitrate in B acid [34]. The diversity of intermediate products highlights the complexity of the reaction. The observed intermediate products suggest that the catalytic combustion of ammonia on 15Cu-CeOx follows both i-SCR and NH mechanisms [29,37]. Fig. 5(b) illustrates the adsorption of nitrogen oxides on the catalyst surface. At low temperatures (below 200 °C), nitrogen oxides are primarily physically adsorbed on the catalyst surface (at 1100–1217 cm−1 and 1620–1650 cm−1) [38]. These physically adsorbed NOx rapidly desorbed with increasing temperature. Some NOx was adsorbed on the catalyst surface as nitrate, including bands at 1440 cm−1 and 1400 cm−1 representing monodentate nitrate. When the temperature reaches 250 °C, new spectral bands appear, including monodentate nitrate near 1215 cm−1, 1245 cm−1, and 1277 cm−1 [39], as well as bidentate nitrate near 1532 cm−1 and 1564 cm−1 [40]. From the figure, it can be observed that the nitrate content increases and then decreases with temperature elevation. This is because, at low temperatures, the rate of nitrate formation is higher than the decomposition rate, leading to nitrate accumulation. As the temperature further increases, the rate of nitrate formation becomes lower than the decomposition rate, resulting in a decrease in nitrate content. 3.2.4 Temperature programmed surface reaction We designed two temperature programmed surface reaction experiments to investigate the mechanism of ammonia catalytic combustion at low temperatures and explore the role of gaseous O2 in the reaction. The specific experimental steps are as follows: a certain amount of catalyst was placed in the reactor, and a gas mixture (2 % NH3, 3 % O2, flow rate of 100 cm3 min−1) was introduced at 100 °C for pre-adsorption, lasting for 60 min. After adsorption, the reactor was purged with N2 (flow rate of 500 cm3 min−1) for 20 min. Subsequently, maintaining a constant N2 flow rate, the catalyst was subjected to programmed heating at 10 °C min−1, ranging from 100 °C to 300 °C. The composition of by-products was monitored throughout the entire heating process. To study the role of gaseous O2, a set of control experiments was designed with steps similar to the above. After purging, a gas mixture containing 3 % O2 (balance N2) was introduced into the reactor. After maintaining for 5 min, the programmed heating was initiated to ensure the presence of 3 % O2 around the catalyst during the heating process. Fig. 6 shows the temperature programmed surface reaction results. In addition, corresponding in-situ DRIFTS experiments were conducted with procedures identical to those above, and the results are shown in Fig. 8. As shown in Fig. 6, during the warming process, the adsorbed NH3 and O2 first react to form N2O and then to form NO. Despite the relatively low concentration of generated NO, its production continues during the subsequent heating process. In contrast, under aerobic conditions, the sequence of by-product generation remains the same, but the quantity produced is significantly lower, with NO generation ceasing at 230 °C. These findings suggest that NH3 adsorbed on the catalyst surface reacts more readily to form N2O, while the presence of O2 promotes the reaction of adsorbed NH3 and O2 to form N2. Fig. 7 (a) illustrates the variation of surface species on the catalyst during the programmed heating process under anaerobic conditions. At 100 °C, a substantial amount of -NH2 (1580 cm−1) appears on the catalyst surface, indicating that the adsorbed NH3 readily undergoes initial dehydrogenation reactions. As the temperature rises, the primary intermediate on the catalyst surface becomes -NH (1456 cm−1). We believe it is attributed to the limited oxygen activity on the catalyst surface, where the adsorbed NH3 can only react through stepwise dehydrogenation and gradual oxidation. The lower oxygen activity restricts the oxidation of -NH, leading to the accumulation of -NH. With further temperature increase, the oxygen activity on the catalyst surface rises, and -NH gradually oxidizes to form NOx. Due to the absence of -NHx reacting with nitrogen oxides, the exhaust gas contains a significant amount of NOx. Additionally, we observed that the surface HNO (1505 cm−1) on the catalyst increases initially and then decreases with temperature elevation, essentially disappearing at 260 °C. This trend aligns with the N2O generation pattern in Fig. 6, suggesting that surface HNO is a crucial intermediate in N2O formation. Fig. 7(b) reflects the changes in surface species on the catalyst under aerobic conditions. It is evident from the figure that the introduction of O2 significantly promotes the oxidation of adsorbed NH3 on the catalyst. This is manifested by the emergence of a new nitrate in the 1525 cm−1 range, and the primary intermediate on the catalyst surface shifts from -NH (1456 cm−1) to nitrate (1476 cm−1). Despite the increased formation of nitrates due to O2 introduction, the concentration of nitrogen oxides in the exhaust gas remains relatively low. We attribute this phenomenon to the fact that O2 promotes the oxidation of ammonia, resulting in the formation of both -NHx and NOx on the catalyst surface, facilitating the key step in the i-SCR mechanism of -NHx + NOx → N2, thereby increasing the selectivity of N2. 3.2.5 In-situ DRIFTS analysis at different oxygen concentrations To investigate the influence of oxygen concentration on the reaction performance, we conducted in-situ DRIFTS experiments on the catalytic combustion of ammonia at different oxygen concentrations, and the results are shown in Fig. 8 . Between 100–300 °C, the two sets of experiments exhibit similar characteristic peaks, but in the temperature range of 300–500 °C, there is a significant difference in the characteristic peaks between the two sets of experiments. This aligns with the results of selective tests under different oxygen concentrations. In Fig. 8(a) (λ = 2), as temperature increases, a substantial amount of nitrate appears on the catalyst surface, with distinct peaks at wavenumbers 1560 cm−1, 1532 cm−1, 1272 cm−1, 1245 cm−1, and 1215 cm−1. Notably, the wavenumbers of these nitrates match those from the NO + O2 experiments, suggesting that these nitrates are formed by the adsorption of NOx generated from the over-oxidation of ammonia on the catalyst surface. At high temperatures, intermediate products such as -NHx are almost undetectable. This is because the high temperature enhances the oxidizing ability of the catalyst, and the ammonia adsorbed on the catalyst's surface is rapidly oxidized to N2 or NOx, so the intermediate products cannot accumulate. Additionally, HNO (1506 cm−1) was not detected at high temperatures. Therefore, we hypothesize that under high-temperature conditions with λ = 2, the reaction of ammonia on the catalyst primarily follows the i-SCR mechanism. According to Fig. 8(b), under the condition of λ = 1, the formation of nitrate salts on the catalyst surface is extremely limited, attributed to the restriction of excessive oxidation of ammonia. To better understand the generation of intermediate products on the catalyst surface, we magnified the spectrum between 250 °C and 500 °C, as shown in Fig. 8(c). We observed a small quantity of nitrate salts on the catalyst surface (at 1560 cm−1, 1476 cm−1, and 1438 cm−1), and their content gradually decreased with increasing temperature, this indicates that the amount of ammonia oxidized by the i-SCR mechanism decreases with increasing temperature. Additionally, we noted a new band representing HNO at 1530 cm−1 [41]. With increasing temperature, the proportion of HNO in intermediate products increased, suggesting that higher temperatures enhance the NH mechanism reaction on the catalyst. In our experiments (supporting information), we observed that in the presence of a catalyst, N2O was rapidly reduced to N2. Therefore, we propose that under λ = 1 condition at high temperatures, the catalytic combustion of ammonia on the catalyst surface primarily follows the NH mechanism, obeying Eqs. In our research, we utilized a lower concentration of reaction atmosphere to mitigate the impact of reaction heat release and gas-phase reactions. The temperature programmed surface reaction did not consider the effect of gaseous NH3 during the reaction. And the conclusions derived from the temperature programmed surface reaction are unsuitable for the combustion environment at high temperatures. To investigate the influence of oxygen concentration on reaction mechanisms, we focused on the reaction of ammonia on the catalyst surface, neglecting the exploration of gas-phase reactions. Future research must integrate theoretical calculations, numerical simulations, and in-situ gas-phase reactions to investigate the effect of gas-phase reactions on ammonia catalytic combustion. 4 Conclusions This study delves into the catalytic performance of CeO2, CuO, and Cu-CeOx catalysts synthesized via the sol-gel method, in which 15Cu-CeOx exhibits superior activity and selectivity. An analysis integrating characterization results indicate that the larger surface area and stronger redox capability of the 15Cu-CeOx catalyst account for its heightened activity. Ammonia combustion on 15Cu-CeOx adheres to the NH and i-SCR mechanisms. Oxygen concentration could impact N2 selectivity at high temperatures, while its effect on the NH3 conversion rate remains relatively minor. At λ = 2, elevated temperatures promote the over-oxidation of NH3, leading to substantial NOx generation during ammonia combustion, primarily following the i-SCR mechanism. Conversely, at λ = 1, the over-oxidation of NH3 is limited, and ammonia combustion primarily follows the NH mechanism. When ammonia combustion complies with the NH mechanism, the main by-product is N2O, which the catalyst facilitates in converting back to N2. Therefore, the design of catalysts tailored to the NH mechanism for ammonia combustion can enhance the N2 selectivity in the reaction. coredata.dc:description: Ammonia has long been regarded as a high-quality zero-carbon fuel; however, limitations in its combustion characteristics have restricted its practical applications. Catalytic combustion is considered an effective solution to overcome the challenges associated with ammonia combustion. In this study, we successfully synthesized a copper-cerium binary catalyst (Cu-CeOx) using the sol-gel method, demonstrating outstanding performance for NH3 catalytic combustion. Through in-situ DRIFTS results, we observed that the 15Cu-CeOx catalyst exhibits both i-SCR and -NH mechanisms. The oxygen concentration affects the N2 selectivity by modulating the overoxidation of NH3. Under high oxygen concentrations, high temperatures promote the excessive oxidation of NH3, and ammonia combustion through the i-SCR mechanism. Conversely, the oxygen concentration was equal to NH3 reaction stoichiometry, the overoxidation of NH3 is limited, and ammonia combustion proceeds through the NH mechanism, resulting in higher N2 selectivity.
